19, 2015
												DO NOT GIVE MONEY TO THIS GAME THROUGH STEAM.  IF YOU DECIDE TO GIVE MONEY TO THIS COMPANY (and I wouldnt advise it.) ONLY USE PREPAID CARDS.The reason for this is if you pay anyway other than prepaid you will get NX credit instead of NX prepaid. Why does it matter? Because you cant buy anything with NX credit (well nothing you would ever want to buy at least).  No you will not get a refund and no there is no way to transfer the NX you bought into a useable form. Please either upvote this review or put an advisory about this in your own review so that people are aware of this when decideing if and how they want to spend money on this game.Thanks

content:
er 29, 2013
												If you're looking for a really fast action MMO, then this is the game for you. It starts off a bit slow but once you select your first class specialization(ie. Warrior-->Barbarian, Mage-->Fire Mage) the game becomes much more intense. The combat is easily the highlight of this game; the feeling of decimating a battlefield with 30 enemies on screen with a giant AoE attack is great! I only feel the character customization is lacking... Options for hair and faces feel limited and classes are gender-locked, so if you want to play as a male Archer, you're outta luck. Overall it's a pretty solid MMO with plenty of dungeons to try your hand at.4/5

content:
31, 2015
												Overall a very fun game. However playing solo can be quite boring sometimes so it's best if you get someone to join with you.As with all games there are pros and cons, the most annoying cons I have found are the gender locked classes, and that certain cash items have to be bought with NX Prepaid (using cards etc.) not with NX Credit (using your credit/debit card and steam cash). Other than that the game is quite enjoyable, and isn't entirely a p2w game like most so called f2p games are.As for PVP, pretty much anyone stands a chance at being good no matter what character they have, it all comes down to skill. Though according to various forums some classes are better than others, but I disagree as I have watched so called OP classes get absolutely destroyed by the so called lower PVP classes.The quests and levelling system can be quite grindy and repetitive at times, but if you're with a friend you dont really mind quite as much since you clear the dungeons quite quickly, most of the time in under 5mins.I highly recommend this game for anyone to try. I was quite sceptical to begin with but have quickly become addicted to playing.

content:
ber 17, 2014
												[Note: this review was so long, it had to be continued in comments - see first reply by me for part 2. Also note that this is not your traditional dot point pro/con 5 second review. This is an editorial piece telling the story of how I fell in love with this amazing game.]Although I like to consider myself a true gamer-girl through and through, I have to admit that there was one single genre I'd never tried - an MMO. The whole "pay to play" thing was a huge hurdle for me when I was a child, and so despite my fascination with the idea of such a large, virtual community, everquest and the like were always out of reach. Fast-forward a decade and times have unsurprisingly changed. With nearly all MMO games becoming free to play, I finally had a chance to try out this genre that had piqued my interest for oh so many years. So around December 2012, I bit the bullet and started trawling through free-to-play MMO's, to see what all the fuss was about. And I have to admit, my first choices did not live up to my expectations. I tried games like Mabinogi and Rose online, but the combat just felt totally clunky and painful. There was little in the way of moving and dodging, with most of the focus simply being on casting skills with incredibly long cast times, and even longer cooldowns. Or alternatively,  just whacking something with a stick over and over ad nauseum, before it keeled over and died. The graphics were bland, the enemies were repetitive, and the story seemed non-existant.  I was beginning to think that I'd been seriously mislead about the nature of MMO's, and that they were all essentially just fancy IRC rooms.But then I installed a lil game called Dragon Nest. Like my previous choices, I spent a large amount of time tinkering around in the character creator, eventually choosing a class called - wait for it - tinkerer. This is a cute little girl of about 13, who, when given the twin pigtail hairstyle, beared more than a striking resemblence to me at that age. The similarities were quite uncanny, which immediately grabbed my attention. Instead of roleplaying, I was simply getting to relive my youthful days as a young teen - something which meant a lot to me, being in my late 20's and utterly depressed at the fact that I'm not far off my thirties. But the other games had nice character creations too, only to be let down by the game itself. So I wasn't all that optimistic about this game either. My pessimism was shattered the instant I entered the game world. After a short introduction scene, I found myself in a beautiful snowy town, decorated with x-mas items and a nice big christmas tree at the centre of town, along with some really cheery christmas-y music. Not only this, but I saw many other characters running around - lil tinkerers like myself, sorcerers, and some rather charming looking clerics. The whole place was very pleasant and inviting, and I really felt a warm welcome to the game and the community as a whole.As I ambled around the town, obtaining main story quests as well as side quests, I noticed that the story behind this game was very well executed, with lots of voice acting on all the main NPC's - a welcome change from static walls of text from mute characters that I'd encountered in nearly all my previous MMO games up to this point. I was also approached by a polite warrior gentlemen, whom, upon noting my newbie status, kindly started explaining many of the concepts of the game to me. He also invited me into his guild, which I was somewhat hesitant about as I didn't feel I would be of any use as a newbie. He assured me it was fine, and that anyone was welcome. I'm glad I accepted the offer because I went on to meet many wonderful people, who taught me a great deal about the game and were more than willing to help me complete tasks on many occasions. Initially however, I chose to complete the dungeons solo, just to get a feel for the combat in this game. This isn't really an open world MMO, you simply have a town with many quests available, and then you have a closed instance field outside of the town for you (and any party members), with several dungeons being accessible from that field. This makes the game suitable for a wide audience, without needing too powerful of a computer (although don't get me wrong, the graphics are very pleasant too!). Upon entering my first dungeon was my next pleasant surprise. The combat in this game is amazing! It was how I'd imagined all MMO's would play, prior to actually playing them. I've been told this style is called an action MMO, and it plays somewhat like a first person shooter / third person shooter, with a huge emphasis on reaction times, dodging, combo'ing, as well as carefully choosing the most ideal order in which to carry out attacks. It's very frantic, but also very rewarding. It's easy to pick up, but very hard to master. Having tried other apparent action MMO's, I have to say that Dragon Nest hands down has the best combat I've ever experienced - it's THAT satisfying. I continued playing through about the first ten levels, but I was alone and in truth the game didn't feel that much different to single player RPG's that I'd played. This all changed when, upon my next visit to town, I was invited to my first party. I think this was the point where the game stole my heart, and I knew that I was going to be playing this for a long time. In fact, I ended up playing for 24 hours straight that very day, it was *that* endearing to me. The game promotes teamwork heavily, with many abilities to help each other out in the form of buffs, debuffs, heals and the like. Not only this, but it was just simply fun to feel a part of something so grand. Even just chatting in town (which we ended up doing for hours) was immensely satisfying, and I met over 30 friends in that first day alone. From this point on, the game consumed me - I played it all day, everyday, whenever I had the free time to do so.  I was really eager to see what would happen next in the main story, while at the same time being happy to party with those of similar level (or even help those at lower level catch up to me). Before I knew it, my friends list was maxed out at 100. I had to tell people to add me and just send me a message whenever they wanted to party, as I had no room left on my list. Such friendships made me feel really happy - something that had been sorely lacking in my real life ever since an incident that left me scarred with PTSD, during which some brutish man tried to kill me (literally) over a road rage incident. He very nearly succeeded too, as he pushed my car towards a tree at 100 miles an hour, which I missed by mere inches. But I digress, this review is about the game not my own injustices.  I merely wished to portray that my friends here really helped me come a long way to recovering from this incident. So back to the game now - at this point I was steadily getting through quests and making my way towards the level cap. So now is probably a good time to talk about the "pay" features that you have in any free to play MMO. Dragon Nest adheres to the policy of paid items being primarily cosmetic in function - this is not a "pay 2 win" game, and there are many well known players who have not paid anything for the game at all, whom are still some of the most powerful and well-geared characters on the server. Of the few items that *do* help make a character more powerful (namely jellies for enhancing items, and stamps for allowing to sell certain high grade items on the market) both of these may be purchased from other players with in-game gold, negating the need to spend real world cash. [Part 2 of review continued in comments to this due to length restrictions. Please don't leave your own comments guys, it will ruin the order of my replies]

content:
er 13, 2015
												For some clarification: I have played this game since Open Beta around September 2011, long before it was released on Steam so I'd average around maybe 5,000 hours give or take a thousand.This game used to be the greatest thing since sliced bread. The combat is phenomenol, still kind of is. The story is gripping although a little trope-y. Most if not all of the classes are unique in their own way, each having their own playstyle. Now why would I not recommend this game despite all the good things, it's only because the cons heavily outweigh the pros.Let's start with content. Content is one of the biggest concerns I have had with this game for a while. The level caps have increased from 16, 24, 32, 40, 50 etc., with each cap including a couple of small 'nests' which are more or less instances with 4-5 bosses with some mechanics built in, a raid which is essentially like the nests only with 8 people instead of 4 and then the hell raid which adds a couple mechanics and makes everything stronger. Each cap lasts about 5-8 months with the exception of 40 cap which lasted nearly a year and some odd months. These months are filled with grinding the same dungeons and 'nests' week to week to try to get the best gear.Now we'll talk about gear. Gear follows a familiar rarity system, Normal, Magic, Rare, Epic, Unique, and Legendary. Normal to Rare is highly disregarded when playing Dragon Nest, if you're seen wearing them you'll be kicked from a party without hesitation, but we'll get into community in a bit. Epic gear is obtained from doing the nests over and over again for materials to craft. There's usually 2 different Epic sets for each cap, one being for magic-based classes, the other being for physical based classes. Unique gear is obtained from completing the normal raid and getting it dropped randomly. Legendary gear is recieved from drops in the hell version of a raid. Essentially to get the best gear in the game you essentially have to just have immense luck, and not to mention a team which can actually clear a raid consistently. Gear does not change any part of attire except for your weapons, so if you're looking to be a fashionista without forking over some cash you're out of luck. When it comes to making your character not look like the average joe, you'll usually have to pay 15-30 dollars on a costume. A lot of the time you won't be able to mix-and-match costumes to get the "ultimate" look just based on the fact that you'll lose a set bonus. These set bonuses get better the more you pay up, and if you ever do feel the need to mix-and-match you'll have to get lucky buying gachapon and getting the single item that allows you to do so, did I mention you need one for each piece of equipment you wish to alter? That's not all, if you're looking to get the highest rarity costumes you'll need to fork over even more cash to get sets and fuse those set pieces together for a CHANCE at a higher rarity costume piece. Good luck!Class balancing is another of the bigger concerns with the game. Every so often there's a balancing patch, when this patch comes around there will ALWAYS be that one class that excells over all the others. This a lot of the time leads to people completely shunning other classes based on their tier list. And when it comes to nerfing a class, the nerf will just be making another class significantly more powerful than the other. If you're thinking about exclusively playing one class and still being able to join up with others then I'm sorry to say that's not the case. Let's get to talking about the community. It's a fairly small game so the community is kind of scrunched up. A lot of the people are generally really nice, but when it comes to actually playing the game, personalities may be a bit skewed. A fair bit of players, especially the people who have been around for a long while, which make up a fair portion of the game, are elitist in one way or another. There is a list of requirements for joining parties ranging from having proper gear, the highest enchantments, the best gems, etc. It doesn't matter if you're trying to learn how to do the latest nest or something to that extent, you will be kicked on the spot if the party leader is not appeased by your gear. This game is without a doubt not friendly to new players, I hate to say.PVP is one of the few things this game has left to offer, and even in that case PVP has had an incessive lag since the game was released till now.I could keep going on and on about all the problems with the game, but I feel I've covered the bare essentials. A couple years ago I would've recommended this game, but unfortunately it just fell into the usual Korean MMO loop of unfortunate cases.

content:
1, 2015
												Note: This review is a bit outdated (It was made at around 70 cap). Some of my complaints might have been addressed at this point but I have not played the game recently so I cannot tell for myself. Fundamentally this review is still accurate though.My steam time for this game is not accurate. I likely have at the very minimum 1,500~ hours in game.tl;dr: Gameplay is solid and suprisingly good with a reasonable amount of depth. However, the grind from lowest level to max level (even with someone grinding you) can be nigh unbearable. The games optimization is hit-or-miss with many players computers as the optimization seems to be based on CPU power with it hardly if at all utilizing the GPU. In terms of class-to-class balance, the actual devs are fairly incompetent at making sure one class doesn't completely dominate the others.In depthGameplay:The gameplay of Dragon-nest is primarily fast-paced combat with heavy reliance on reflexes, ability to predict the enemy movements, and knowing your own skills. The combat has no casting bars rather relying on animations which makes you feel as though you are 'in control'. Many of the higher level skills do a satisfying amount of damage in PvE and a reasonable amount in PvP. In my experience, the end-game content (Dragon nests) often devolve DPS races to blow up the boss before it has a chance to do any of it's harder mechanics. Simply getting hit by some of these bosses could result in an instant death for you. Note: In the end-game content, after you die, you are dead until the raid (called 'nest' ingame) is complete or your entire party dies.PVP:PVP deserves it's own section because for many players it is simply all that matters in the game. PVP is largely player-skill based as a highly skilled player can easily combo the other player to death, giving the other player no opportunities to fight back. There are a few types of PVP in Dragon Nest which I will describe quite simply. There is Ladder, Endless, 1v1, and blacklisted 1v1.Ladder is what many players might call 'competitive' mode with a rating, but in reality, it is simply an infestation of a single class. Gear plays a role in this mode and for many PVP'ers, no one actually cares about it, since gauging it as a metric of skill is completely stupid.Endless is simply 8v8 combat. Given its playercount, it is easily the laggiest mode for many players and, simply put, is a mind-less cesspool of high AOE skill-spamming. Gear does not matter.1v1 is what it is. Gear does not matter.Blacklisted 1v1 is different from what you might expect it to be. To give it a bit of a background, many players view some skills as overpowered compared to other skills (example: A mercenary's 'Iron Skin'). Most classes have a few of these skills and players will mutally agree to not use these skills. For some players, Blacklisted 1v1 might include entire classes or very specific rulesets and for many players, what is blacklisted to someone might not be blacklisted to the other. Most 'legitimate PVP'ers' play this.One other 'important' aspect about PVP is PVP rank. PVP rank is arguably important because there is an icon associated with your rank. Initially, it is a brown egg icon next to your name. As you PVP more, you get more experience and the icon changes. The other icons are blue (silver) and yellow (gold). However, be warned, the blue and yellow icons are EXTREMELY difficult to attain as they are exclusive to a certain rising XP threshold. It is difficult to describe in words but simply put, if you were to attempt to become the player with the #1 amount of experience, it would easily take you a year of pvp'ing to get even close to it.Sound:The sounds of Dragon Nest are fairly average I would personally say, although, one of the key issues many players seem to have is that the voice-actors for some of the classes are borderline cringeworthy, prompting some users to completely disable the voice or download a foriegn language voice mod. Another one of the issues and to many players and advantage is that most if not all the skills have their own special voice-line for casting that spell. This means when your Adept (that's a class) casts Inject, every single time you are going to hear what sounds like a child say, "This might sting a bit!" Graphics:The graphics are good and fantastic for many of the skills. However, some classes and raids (nests) in particular have crippling effects on many player's computers. One class in particular, the Alchemist, has a few spells that are strong in PvP simply because for many players, casting it is 'like opening six movies at the exact same time', resulting in a crippling half-second burst of lag.Community:The community of Dragon Nest is fairly odd. A mix of Anime fanatics and normal people coupled with a loud creepy population. The population seems to be a mix of 12 to 19 year olds with some guilds greatly skewing this margin. I highly recommend finding a guild that suits your playstyle rather than joining one of the ones that you get invited to right off the bat. The best way to do that is make a friend in-game and try their guild. Server & Game Issues:The server occasionally seems to have frustrating issues with lag. Sometimes these issues are extremely frustrating as they might completely void and entire 'nest', leading to a player missing out on loot. One of the most notable issues is the completely unavoidable 'Hackshield', and instant kick from the game resulting in the failure of the games anti-cheat. It is not detecting a false-positive, merely it just messes up.Pay-to-win Factor:Suprisingly, this game isn't nearly as pay to win as I expected. The only pay-2-win'ish factor seems to be Dragon eggs and, even then, the only good thing that comes from them is wings which boost your characters movement speed in everything but PVP. When it comes to costumes, 'green' costumes boost stats which can pretty much only be purchased through NX (real life money). However, 'blue' costumes which boost stats much greater than 'green' costumes can only be reliably purchased through large amounts of ingame gold.Overall: The game is suprisingly good but has a good few problems that detract from some of the good parts. The game seems to have a large issue when it comes to grinding of either money or levels. There are minor issues with the community regarding it's vocal immature side.

content:
, 2015
												[EDIT: Dragon Nest is not associated with Nexon anymore. Although this review is outdated, the leveling guide is still updated. Please take a look at that.]*A LENGTHY REVIEW*Background Information:Dragon Nest is a free-to-play fantasy MMORPG published by Nexon NA (Steam Version). Play Style/Game PlayIt uses a non-targeting combat system (which most MMORPG have), so basically you have full control of the players movement using the keys "W, A, S, D". You are able to use your skills using the short cut keys "1-10" or change your key bindings to see which better suits you. Dragon nest consists of 2 game modes or 2 of both, PvP and PvE. You start off as PvE but later through the levels you can change to PvP or do both. The game consists of 8 Characters of which they have their own unique skills and abilities. ClassesClasses have 'specialisations' where they can change into their first and second job and focus on that particular area of combat. Specialisations are granted at level 15 and level 44. The 8 classes include: Warrior Archer Cleric Sorceress  Tinkerer Kali Assassin LanceaFor more information of the classes and what specialisations they have go to the Nexon website @ http://dragonnest.nexon.net/guides/class-guideLike every game they have their pros and their cons. Here are mine:Pros:+Gameplay system. The choice of movement and mechanics are great+Community. Everyone is nice but you do get the occasional person that isn't so nice+Exp rate. There are so many opportunities you get with bonus exp to level up your character as fast as possible+Simple. Easy to learn but takes practice to learn the mechanics of the characters. Practice makes perfectCons:-The lack of designing your character. The class you choose has already determined of what type and style you are. You don't really have that much of a choice to change your personal features, and the gender has been set to that class.-Repetitive. The game can get a little repetitive at times, doing the same dungeons over and over again. But it isn't really that much of a bother if you have a friend to play with youOverallI've played Dragon Nest when it was in Beta, but I've kept quitting and coming back 3 times. I've finally stuck with the game. Leveling can be hard at times and you have no choice but to the grind to get to the level you desire, but that's with most MMORPGs. When I reached the level cap, I thought it was worth all the hard times of grinding. You'll think that reaching the max level will be the end, but it's a whole new chapter and there are far more things to do and goals to be set.Here's my friend's guide for leveling:


Alch's DN Guide! (93 Cap!) 
A Guide for Dragon Nest
By: alch

			The #1 DN guide on Steam! Please favorite if you already haven't! LAST UPDATE - 1/15/2017		


tl;dr. it's good. Feel free to add me or ask me any questions in the comments!

content:
y 9
												Hi everyone, this is honestly more personal than anyting but I want someone to hear me out and maybe find someone who can relate to me.I reviewed this game a few years back in 2013, and recommended it but now that has changed. Dragon Nest now is not the same game compared to the launch date 2010-2015. Let me list my basic points.- Difficulty of the game• Removal of difficulty modes such as Hard, Master, Abyss in multiple dungeons• Monsters and Bosses dying upon one hit• The ability to level up quickly and surpass the area/nest/quest, essentially posing no challenge for players- Nests• The removal of nest such as the Level 32 Cerebus Nest or Level 40 Apocalyse Nest- Removal of Items• Due to the removal of nest, players can no longer find or craft armor exclusive to the nest for their level,items include: Elf Queen set or Cerebus set • Generic and general armor pieces with the rarity of Rare and Epic, the lack of oppertunity to enchance armor found unless it is of the Epic rarityIn conclusion the game was reworked where it was no longer about the journey, but the ending. This is not how any MMORPG should function. What lead to these changes and why? Dragon Nest has, been, is and remain my favorite MMORPG, no other game will beat the charm this game had and the memories I had created. It is extremely sad and disappointing to see what has happened to it in just 2 years. This game got me into gaming, and kept me in gaming but now I can only reflect on what the game was but no longer have the ability to replay and relive those moments again.Thank you for reading, I wish this for this to reach out to the game makers/company/publisher or anyone who will just hear me out as someone who has been apart of Dragon Nest since 2011.

content:
y 11, 2015
What is this gameDragon Nest is a Free to Play MMO Action RPG with an anime-like art style. This game features fast paced combat, skill shot/aiming mechanics and 8 different classes. Unlike WoW or many other MMOs, the game isn’t open world, and most of everything is instance based.ClassesAssassin: Deadly martial artist that deals burst dmg. Builds Str and Agi. Shinobi: Focuses more on dealing phys dmg. Taoist: Focuses more on supporting allies with Light and Dark powersKali: Spiritual dancer that debuffs enemies and supports allies. Builds Str and Int. Dancer: Focuses more on dealing damage. Screamer: Focuses more on debuffing and buffing.Sorceress: Female mage class that deals magic damage (Duh). Builds Int. Mystic: Focuses more on Dark and Light spells/dmg. Elementalist: Focuses more on Ice and Fire spells/dmg.Warrior: Melee sword fighter. Builds Str and Vit. Swordsman: Focuses on slash attacks. Mercenary: Focuses on knocking down enemies.Archer: Elf ranged bow class that focuses on dps (Duh). Builds Agi. Sharpshooter: Focuses on single target dps. Acrobat: Focuses on aerial combat.Cleric: Holy magic class that buffs allies and heals them. Builds Str and Vit. Paladin: Focuses on tanking up allies Priest: Focuses on healing allies.Tinkerer/Academic: Jack of all trades class. Builds Agi and Int. Engineer: Focuses on doing physical damage with robots and guns. Alchemist: Focuses on doing magical debuffs and supporting allies.Lencea: Spear/lance user thats not in the NA version as of the beginning of January 2015. Builds Str and Int.Why did I start playingA friend suggested that I and another friend should try this game out since he previously played it back in 2012. So I installed it, thinking it would one of those F2P games that I would play for 20 hours and stop playing. My friend had a Sorceress from before and my other friend made a Tinkerer, so I decided to make an Assassin. I specialized him to Taoist, leveled him to 20, and got bored with him. I saw that the Tinkerer can summon a giant robot and hit things with a giant wrench, which reminded me of Max from Dark Cloud 2, so I made one. When I got to choose a Job Specialization, my friend had previously made his an Engineer, so I made mine an Alchemist. This is when I really dove into the game, finding out that most of the Alchemist’s abilities are really fun to use. At level 45, I got to choose a second job specialization; the Adept’s increased Fire and Ice power or the Physician’s increased Poison and Healing power. I chose Physician because I like playing healers. Now I have 350+ hours in the game and probably not stopping soon. Why do I like this gameI like it mainly because it’s an action RPG with fast-paced fighting and I love action RPGs. This game is not a freemium at all and very little pay to win(costume items give very little stats, and you can buy item protection jellies and revives with real money).Why should/shouldn’t you play itWhile the gameplay is fun, I have many problems with it. Bandwagoning: Raid parties tend to favor certain classes/specs over others and instantly kick the ones that are not meta. My main class, Physician is one of those non-meta classes and I have trouble finding parties since people favor Light Bringers over Priests and Physicians. This is due to the whole “Light Party” meta that is pretty much centered around Light Bringers, Crusaders/Inquisitors and Light converted DPS classes.Bad model textures: The textures in my opinion are low quality and unappealing.Annoying voices: 80% characters in the game have very cheesy lines.The Tinkerer is a 11 year old girl: The Tinkerer is commonly referred as the “Loli Class,” and the fact that I main one makes me feel like a pedo. I just like their skillset that’s all. There many reasons why I feel people don’t play this game. First is the anime-esque art style, since a lot people dislike anime. Second is that the graphics’ quality is bad. Third is the niche community of mostly otakus and weeaboos. Overall what do thinkI really enjoy this game. I find the gameplay fun and interesting with a high amount of replay value. I would suggest people to at least try it out to see if you like it or not. This is a good game to delve into if you are bored, so I pretty much recommend this for people to play.

er 4, 2014
												There's something about Dragon Nest that sets it apart from Nexon's other major action-MMO title Vindictus. It certainly has the anime style charm to it and tons of humor behind many of its characters and quests. but I feel its easier to immerse myself into the game as a whole. The combat is fun and the while the classes are genderlocked you don't really mind that fact once you start playing. I will always come back to this game when I want my fill of hack and slash adventure!

content:
, 2014
												The graphics are adorable. The dialog of your character and the NPCs is hilarious. There are plenty of powerful and dazzling skills to spam. There are a huge number of quests to complete. You can journey through the game solo or with friends - I REALLY like games that give you both options. All in all, this is a very fun MMORPG that does a good job of combining pure action and RPG elements. It may take a bit of practice at first to get the hang of it but give it a chance and you won't regret it.

number of helpful: 28 of 32 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
er 8, 2013
												Dragon Nest is an instance-based action RPG playing much like an arcade game with no targeting, a strict class tree, a less strict skill tree, and more or less no character customization whatsoever. For instance, all Tinkerers are time-travelers who somehow turned into adorable lolitas, and all Kalis are abundantly female spirit dancers with sweet, slightly shy temperaments and dead masters.Masters in their tribal ninja teachings, not BDSM masters. Moving along.Dragon Nest's English localization is -incredibly- well-done, with dialogue that is not only legible but actually full of character and humor. The voice acting is goofy, but in a way that lines up with the character in question. The child king is nasally and distinctly lacking a courtly presence, while the storage NPC constantly complains about the horrible things other people / you leave in storage. The marketplace NPC will insult you for being poor (regardless of how much money you are holding because he's so damn rich.)Dungeons have multiple difficulty settings, and the baddest ♥♥♥ dungeons are the titular Nests (though not necessarily dragon nests.) Abyss is the fourth and highest difficulty of any other dungeon, but it is the first difficulty of a Nest, and most of them have a Hell or Hardcore one that's much much harder than that. Nests are effectively your chokepoints for progress through the game, and at any given time one or more Nests will be the "endgame" dungeon. The catch is, you can only /win/ one given Nest a limited number of times every week. You can fail as many times as you want, but the great majority of items from Nests are only acquired after a successful clear.Sadly, despite its charms, some significant flaws mar Dragon Nest and detract largely from its otherwise polished gameplay:- As said before, character customization barely exists and development is largely one-way-only - there isn't as freeform choice in character build as there would be in a standard MMO like WoW or Everquest II. It's basically an online arcade game.- It is possible to miss content. This is usually something trivial such as a non-title achievement, but it will still drive completionists up the wall.- The game is entirely instance dungeon-based with little to no open world. The exploration fields don't have any combat in them, nor any content other than NPC's to talk to and gates into instance dungeons (similarly to Sonic Adventure.) This can make the game feel very railroaded and monotonous.- Costume items, which are largely cash-only and non-tradeable, also give you stats and perks. This means they're not costumes. They're cash-only equipment.- Titles also give you stats, but the majority of those are acquired ordinarily ingame and you may use a display title different from your stat title.- As with most if not all other free games that have equipment upgrades available, Dragon Nest's equipment upgrade rate is abysmal without paying cash to improve it and/or protect items from destruction. These items thankfully can be traded, but as cash items they will cost a small fortune.- Holiday events, and events in general, almost never give anything permanent and unique. They give consumables and temporary costumes at best, or items that can be obtained in normal gameplay. They're generally quite underwhelming and unrewarding.- The keyboard control scheme is VERY awkward and can't be remapped.- If you like endowed girls at all you won't be able to play as Kali, because she's constant softcore pornography on the screen and very distracting. She's the only character with jiggle (Archer / Sorceress / Tinkerer are all B-cup or less whereas she's at least a D-cup with a huge butt) and her dance animations border on profane. This is especially jarring given her dialogue is written as though she is very sweet and innocent.Despite these flaws, the game is colorful and fun with only a couple friends. You can form guilds, but only four-odd of you can run a dungeon at once anyway, so you don't need to bring a legion.And Tinkerer is SUPER CUTE. Give it a shot and see if you like it.

number of helpful: 26 of 29 people (90%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 14, 2014
												I was looking for a new MMO that had fun and challenging PvP and most of all, a story to really IMMERSE myself in. That is what gets me hooked on a game. I made the awful mistake of summing up this MMO with many J/KRPGs out there. I think most of these have very cliched story lines or have poorly written scripts. But Dragon Nest is not the case. If you're a fan of reading quests and PVP, this is definitely a game to try.The story begins differently for each and every class you choose. Granted, they fit into the typical anime character archtypes, the boy who never gives up, the mysterious and talented but silent hero. However, their stories are interwoven in such a way that the characters interact somewhat differently with the NPC dialogues, making it interesting for different perspectives on the main story quest line.As for the state of the game, the devs and GMs seem to pay attention and have interest in retaining their population as well. Spontaneous events occur that you simply click on and teleport to an instance for all sorts of strange games, some familiar and fun with great rewards at the end. The community seems to be tight knit, and the servers swell every time a new content pack is released, and then over the course of two months, dwindles back to a steady population. This is common and expected for most "themepark" type MMOs such as WoW as opposed to "sandbox" types like EVE online.The gameplay is very fluid, and each class has a large array of flashy skills that make watching their animations very enjoyable every single time. Learning combinations and stacking them is highly addicting. The only thing that feels a bit weird is jumping, there is a very slight pause before taking off from the ground, but this is probably intended this way for fairness in PVP. In a game like Dragon Nest, bunny hopping could be an issue especially with melee classes. MODS! There are mods for this game from intricate skins to voice packs. In most youtube videos, you often hear the characters in the Korean / Japanese voice overs. Admittedly, I installed a Japanese voice pack and mixed it up with Korean as well. I understand neither of the language. But the game sounds MUCH better. The dialogue and the quests are completely in English. Even the cutscenes will not be a problem as they are completely captioned. It gives a more arcade feel to the game.Overall, Dragon Nest is a game that is definitely worth playing and worth recommending. Given Nexons track record on their game development, I feel that Dragon Nest is one of their better games and I hope the community grows and Nexon continues to support Dragon Nest. With its addition to steam, a steady influx of new players decide to give this game a try. It's very newb friendly if this is a beginning MMO for you, and free to play. Give Dragon Nest a shot!

content:
7
												It shatters my heart to write a negative review for Dragon Nest. I only have 60.4 hours on steam but I played Dragon Nest before it was on Steam for 1000+ hours. When I started playing, the level cap was 40 and there was only 4 classes. I was never particulary "good" at the game as I only made it to level cap once when the cap was 40. However, 3-4 years ago, this game was just a ♥♥♥♥ing blast. You could play on Abyss difficulty which made the endless grind feel more like a challenging but rewarding adventure. I was never a succesful player but I remember getting so excited over new gear I saved up for a long time by getting Goddess Tear Drops. But now with the level 93 cap, this game is just dead. The added classes are honestly incredible and really diversifies gameplay. The problem is the 1-93 grind is so painfully boring due to limitations on what difficulty you can play. If that wasn't enough, you'll have a hard time trying to find people to play with. It's really a shame because when the game was active, the mentor system worked so well in trying to help your friends get to your rank and really gave an incentive for playing with other people of all ranks. The Goddess Tear Drops and mentor system all still exist which is great. It's just the fundamental aspects of an MMO are compltely and utterly GONE. The market is dead. I mention this because the marketplace used to be PACKED by dozens of people on every server when this game was alive and well. The combat, which is so incredible it kept this game alive far past the time it probably should have actually died; has been made more boring as dungeons have suddenly gotten ridicously easy. I am begging, and I mean BEGGING for Dragon Nest to be shut down in favor of a Dragon Nest 2 with updated graphics, balances, a sensible level cap between 40-93, and less pay-to-win schemes. The arcade-like feel of Dragon Nest makes it unique compared to other MMOs even after so many years that have seen bold competitors enter the MMO market. If they brought Dragon Nest to the next generation with a second installment, everyday gamers would fall head over heals for it. But for now, please don't support the current version.

content:
31, 2014
												Edit: It seems the developers of this game have really sped up the update pace, which is good and slightly alleviates some of the issues.While it's combat is great and it sure did have a lot of potential as a game and is even actually enjoyable when things are fresh, it's not something I'd recommend playing in the long run if you're looking for something to invest a decent amount of time into. This is due to quite a few reasons, the combat is great and there was/is potential but the game has fell short in literally anything that isn't combat since release and continues to do so with no signs and a incredibly small chance of ever being fixed.Lets start off with a few issues-Lag is common-PvP is not balanced and never will be most likely-PvE is not balanced and never will be most likely-New classes always eclipse previous ones and are overpowered in one way or another in order to promote new characters and purchases of costumes and other things for these new characters (A trend common in F2P titles). The community also supports this (Goes along with it IE: Bandwagonning,etc) and will not allow you to join parties if you're playing a class that isn't as good as some of the others sometimes.-RNG is HUGE in this game and very good at screwing you over with it (Probably in part to get you to pay for items you need to safely enhance gear instead of investing large amounts of time in getting gold just to try again)-Sub classes of each main class usually change from which one is best to again, promote buying class change scrolls and what not for money.-The graphics are worse than something from 2005 and the game is not optimized at all or something is totally broken. Even with current hardware don't expect 60 fps, it's always been like this.-A lot of the really nice purchasable things like mounts, wings, weapon skins and other things are only obtainable by dragon eggs. It's like a gachapon/lottery with a really small chance to get the items that are actually worth anything, usually you just get junk. Eggs aren't cheap either, $1.50 per single Egg and $30 for a 30 pack. You might not even get one of the good things you hoped for by spending that much either, there's people who pay hundreds to get certain items.Now none of this is the main issue with this game nor are these all the issues. I'd say the main problem with this game is the roots of it, the way the game is designed. The game is instanced based with town world hubs. You have dungeons with monsters and a boss at the end and nests/raids which you can do a certain amount of times a week. -Dungeons are useful for leveling up till cap. -Nests are useful for getting drops towards crafting gear and other things. -Raids are for end game gear, there's also a hardcore version. -Dailies can be done once you reach cap, dailies consist of doing the current cap dungeons in order to get certain items that are useful. So here's the deal, level caps come with 1) Filler content (Constant class rebalancing and fixes that never actually fix anything and just shift power for money) 2) A new set of dungeons3) New nests and raid for each cap4) A new classYou'll get one good update every 1~3months with others being nothing special (Subject to change of course, I no longer keep up with the update pace/quality as of recently)So.. here we go, you put so much effort and time into content which is not fun for more than a week at most in order to be able to be strong enough to enjoy the new good content that comes out every 1~3months. This content is usually fun for a week at most (Excluding raids which take more time to master/beat through typically). You do dailies every single day (if you can stand doing them), nests every week (that are boring once you've learned them which takes about a week because it's literally doing the same thing every time you do them over and over which goes for any content released in this game) and the same applies to raids after a bit too. You also grind dungeons for drops, maybe grind some other various things the game has for gold and that's.. it. The game itself is fun, the combat is good and all that but all you're doing in the game is the same thing over and over and over every day in order to gear up which takes time just so you can enjoy and participate in the end game raids. There's nothing else to do, it's all instance based and not open world so you're doing this or afking.. It's just.. a shame, it's not worth your time. You'll have fun at first but by the end of it the boring, repetitive, and chore like content you need to do to get strong every day and week heavily outweighs the fun you'll have with new fresh content. Again, this is only the main flaw and only a flaw to those who aren't playing the game casually, there's a million other problems to this game stacked on top of it that I haven't mentioned aside from how static it is. There's better stuff out there to enjoy and Black Desert is coming too which has potential. If you're looking to play a game and enjoy/invest your time in it and have fun (The reason most people play games in general), this isn't for you. It's a great game to casually play though as the combat really is just that good.~Person who's played this game since close to the initial release

content:
14
												It truly breaks my heart giving this game a negative review. This game used to be my most favorite MMORPG, simply from its action-oriented and non-targetting combat style, w/ its good community (from what I saw). Don't be misjudged by my hours of playtime, I had to run it on Nexon as for some reason the steam version never worked for me.So, what's so bad about it now?For starters, the playerbase is basically dead. I predict a few more months or maybe some years, and the game will be completely dried out of players. If you're new, wanting to play, you most likely won't come across anyone who will play w/ you as most are just lvl 90+, and have no interest in doing such little tasks for a person who will inevitably get bored and leave. That brings me to my next point: The level cap. Before, the level cap was 60-70, a good level cap for this game in my opinion. However, apparently from the time I was on hiatus until recently, they've changed the cap to 93 (I think)So, instead of fun dungeon-crawling with random people or guild-mates, you're stuck basically grinding alone in a dead server to reach 93 and get some actual good stuff.3-4 years ago, this game WAS MY LIFE. I would NOT stop gawking about it to friends, trying to get them to play, then them join and have a blast w/ me. Now?Now it's a dead place with hardly any chat in global andno one to dungeon crawl with (which, people to hang out with was one of the best parts, and grinding to such a level on your own would eventually wear you out). Just that, is enough to pull me away from this. Now something for all those verteran players like me, that kinda set us off. Apparently, around september 2016 and before, you could switch your account to EYEDenity (Nexon had control over DN first, then it was switched to Eyedenity). HOWEVER, if you didn't transfer it between that deadline, all your content was erased. Yep. MEANING, If you have a lvl 70 character, with some REALLY good gear, and you payed REAL LIFE Money on the game, that was all for nothing, as it was erased on the transfer. Granted, I never spent a dime on it, but it aggitated me, trying to use my Nexon account, finding out it wont work, and having that ONE Character I spent hours upon hours to get to lvl 50 with a single friend, which the file had a lot of memories for me. It's a sad tale, a wonderful game turned into.... this. Sorry to say, but I can't recommend it :(.

												I figure i've played long enough at this point to write a review.To begin, the combat in this game is really satisfying. You cannot expect to faceroll everything and walk away with your life, you need to pay attention to enemy attacks and dodge accordingly. Especially in Nests (boss raids) as you cannot use health potions (though support classes do exist, and they have party heals)  inside Nests, so being careful and dodging properly is especially important.There are many different classes, each with their own unique playstyle. Whether you want to play a close range Archer who specializes in kicks and hurricane attacks, an Ice Witch who flings off a relentless barrage of ice spells and turns everything into ice cubes, or maybe you feel like playing a Stank-a** Cleric who drops totems on the field and explodes them or some s***. You get the point, there's a ton of different classes.Best of all? No more Nexon.  If you're a fan of Fast-Paced Action-RPGs with Giant Dragons and s***, try the game. You won't regret it.

number of helpful: 9 of 10 people (90%) found this review helpful
content:
r 6, 2016
												So, I've hit 200 hours in Dragon Nest, and I've compiled some information for everyone who may be wondering, "Is it worth playing?"In short, YES.Here's a Pros-Cons List.Pros:-Extremely fun, fluid, face-paced, intense action combat-NOT pay-2-win AT ALL. Especially compared to other games in this genre.-PvP is REALLY fun too-SO many classes to choose from. All are unique-Leveling up characters isn't horrible-Good community-In-game economy is pretty good, compared to other MMOs-You can cosmetically and audio mod it a little bit to your liking (with help from Google that is, I won't tell you how here.)-Game has been going long and strong since lvl 40 cap, now at 93 cap-Nexon hasn't ruined it don't worry. -New publisher seems very nice, although they have that Engrish.-You earn a +50% EXP bonus to every character on the account (Up to 250%) for each character you have at max level.-You won't need to pay for character expansions (You get 25 character slots)-You won't need to pay for inventory expansions (You get 4/5 30-slot bags to carry all your stuff)-Events for free pets (which pick up items) are every holiday.-Cash shop items can be earned for free, because of events.- +200% EXP Scrolls that last for 7 days can be purchased for $2.50 and will easily get you to max level if you grind moderately (3-4 hours a day) for a few (4-7) days.Cons:-Leveling can be tedious sometimes (running the same dungeon 20 times to get one level, UNLESS you have capped characters.)-If you don't have any gold in the beginning, it's hard to earn it right off the bat (only for your first character though)-Slight learning curve for those unfamiliar with games of this type-Cash shop armor is incredibly expensive, $28 for one permanent set for one character (although at max level it won't be hard to earn the gold to buy from other players)-Cash shop armor has some unfair stats. For example: One weapon gives +800 Phys. and Magic Damage, but at the max level that's hardly notable. (but, it's all earnable from playing the game and buying it from other players)-Cash shop gacha is expensive, and gives some really good items, still not pay to win though.Summary:Yes, it's worth playing. I recommend it. You can play and be a good player without paying. Convenience for leveling can be speeded up with cash shop items, and some cash armors give considerable stat boosts, but nothing so unfair that you will want to quit the game.

content:
y 7, 2016
												Now, the veterans can defend this game all they like, but I started playing the game around the day that the infamous level 90 patch came out so let me release a review from the viewpoint of a new play who has reach level 75 and stopped playing due to immense boredomPros>Combat System-The combat system is the only thing that this game has going for it, you can pull intricate strings of combos and abilities>Classes-Each class is unique and awesome, I love how they all lookCons>EVERYTHING ELSE!-Let me elaborate>Any dungeons below level 90 are SUPER MEGA ULTRA..... easy-Apparently, these dungeons USED to be difficult, but they decided to completely F***ING remove the hardest difficulties for all low level dungeons. The nests are easy when they used to require a party, (I MEAN FOR GOD'S SAKE, YOU'RE NOT EVEN ALLOWED TO PARTY FOR THE FIRST NEST) you take no damage while the enemies all die in one hit, and you can't even stumble over to higher level dungeons if you want a challenge because it's barred by a level cap, and by the time you reach the recommended level for the dungeon, it'll be too easy. I was waiting for the game to get difficult FOR 75 LEVELS. I WAS ONE SHOTTING EVERY ENEMY AND BOSS IN EVERY DUNGEON FOR 75 LEVELS! At that point, if the game can provide zero excitement for what was essentially 70% of the game, then it's not good game design. And I'm patient, oh I'm very patient, I'm always willing to give a game a chance, but this game could not impress me, it took too long.>Story missions progress way too slowly-I won't talk too much for this one. Basically, once you reach level 60, the dungeons that you have to traverse through for the story will have a recommended level of 45. Not to mention, really intimidating monsters appear in the story cutscenes a lot, and you end up getting excited at the fact that you'll be able to finally get a challenge, only to have your  character get stomped on in the cutscene and have the bad guy run off with the important McGuffin that you were sent to chase after and you instead have to fight some insignificant boss, that just basically ends up becoming a miniboss in later dungeons. But hey, at least there's occasional voice acting and almost every character has a unique personality why you can then elborate on through giving them gifts, but that's only fun if you're actually interested in this game's story.>PvP is "Balanced"-Unless you're playing with friends who are around the same level as you, you're essentially not allowed to PvP until you're level 90. Oh, don't worry though, there's and equalizer put into play so that your stats are basically increased to what they would be around level 90. The problem is that your skills still do garbage damage against players who have more points put into their skill trees, have better armor, and have learned their combos while you have nothing to protect yourself with.. The equalizer just makes killing you take like 30 more seconds than it should.Don't play this game unless you have a time machine. I've heard countless good things about the game before the update, all things that I wish I could've been a part of, but from what I can guess, the developers wanted to make it easier to reach level 90 to appeal to players who want have level 90 characters for all the classes, and for some reason they decided to remove content that didn't need to be removed in the first place.

content:
, 2016
												TL;DR It's a solid title- worth a look, for sure. ^.^I played a little of Dragon Nest waaaay back when (maybe a little of the beta?), and put in maybe ~20 hours or so before I downloaded this on Steam.Anyhoo- from a gameplay perspective, Dragon Nest resembles Vindictus. You choose a (gender-locked) class, run around a shared town hub and accept quests, then delve into instanced dungeons, slay monsters to transition between areas, and face a boss in the final room.I'll get a bit more specific...GAMEPLAY- As outlined above.You do learn new skills fairly quickly, which are infinitely more entertaining to use than your basic attack combos. There's a level up reward chest you can open every time you level up, as seen in several f2p titles. Dragon Nest has... taken an interesting approach with their iteration; at level 6, you are granted a costume set that- when equipped- grants your character hp and damage far beyond normal means. It will essentially trivialize most content you come across, and is on a 7-day timer. A second identical set is granted at another level, but I forget what it was, exactly...That being said, it's a lovely little feature if you've played before and want to barrel through story and get into the meatier content. I'm not sure if such a system would be detrimental to a new player's experience- if a time comes when the items expire and that overwhelming power is lost, it may be a bit of a shock having to suddenly rely on player skill and skill synergies... although to be fair, joining parties/guild may help alleviate that issue... I can't assert anything on that issue quite yet.GRPAHICS- Cute, albeit simplistic aesthetic.Most things (the older assets for sure) are noticeably low-poly, but it looks like a lot of love went into the textures. The effects on most skills are bright and flashy, and could end up obscuring gameplay in larger groups. But solo, I've had no problem keeping up with things.Once again comparing this to Vindictus, Dragon Nest is considerably more gentle on my computer's aged hardware. I honestly think a laptop less than 5 years old could handle this pretty well.STORY- It actually has one, and it's pretty good.The story arc you experience differs to some degree between each class. Sometimes a lot, sometimes a little. Dialogue is generally pretty funny and light, but there are heavier plot points here and there. Characters are a little... melodramatic, perhaps. But I find I like more characters than I find annoying... so that's nice.AUDIO/SOUND/MUSIC- Nothing really stands out, but nothing's downright terrible... not even the voice-acting.Sound effects are loud and bombastic. Music is decent, but the loops are relatively short and can overstay their welcome before too long, so I've disabled it. My biggest complaint is that ambient sounds are directly tied to music, so with that muted, towns and forests sound dead... but still- just queue up your own playlist or internet radio or podcast or whatever. :PCOMMUNITY- Haven't had a lot of dealings with people yet, but things don't seem particularly toxic, at any rate.There's one server, broken up into channels. I've made a point to select low-pop channels just to avoid crowds, but global chat has stayed relatively quiet. I have no idea if there are just that few people playing, or if more conversations are simply being held in party/guild chat... I certainly hope Dragon Nest isn't "dying", as I do find it rather enjoyable.CASH SHOP- Doesn't appear to be buy-to-win..?Basic cosmetics (costumes, and a few exclusive faces and hairstyles for most classes), crafting boosters and whatnot. I have yet to purchase anything, and don't feel like I really have to. I call that a win.EXTRA- Just some little tidbits I didn't work into the fields above.-There's a mercenary system that lets any class bring a "combat pet" of sorts into dungeons. It IS stuck behind a few walls; beyond the three starter mercs (which you will be able to choose one upon completing a lvl24 quest), the rare and epic varieties have to either be grinded for, or bought off of the player marketplace. Some of the available mercanaries are npc's from certain class' storylines, so even if you don't really NEED a mercanary, it can be entertaining to battle along side them, and see them toss out a one-liner once a dungeon is cleared... could become more necessary once those super-costume items expire, and you aren't running with a party/guild.-There's PvP available as early as lvl10, but it's something I've not touched, nor really plan to... like other games, there is a PvP based currency and a variety of items to be bought.-MOST classes, with the exception of the Lancea, Machina, and two elite classes, will recieve a specialization quest at lvl15, and can subsequently choose one of two secondary classes. This choice grants a second skill tree to develop and populate your hotbar with. The skills from this second tree generally require a certain weapon type be wielded, so bear that in mind when the time comes. For the classes with no specialization choice, your second skill tree simply unlocks when you reach lvl15.-Building on that, your choice of weapon type affects your basic attacks/combos. You'll begin with a starter weapon of each type, so try them out early on and get a feel for them. ^.^Think that's it... again, I've yet to experience the full gamut of what Dragon Nest has to offer, so please correct me if I'm wrong about something. o3o

												Spent a lot of hours playing this with my girlfriend, been too long since I last played but I highly suggest. Great game, lot of fun played with a party, less fun playing alone but still a good experience for anyone who likes RPG games. The combat is probably my favourite thing about the game, real-time action and a lot of moving around and dodging. The graphics are still really good and can run on older computers with no problem. The only critique I can make, as well as being an aspect that I really like and something unique about the game is the session-based arenas in which all combat takes place. On one hand I quite like having them in sessions and having a set objective and path each time, but it becomes repititive if you have to complete several quests over some levels in the exact same area. I do, however, enjoy having to master each location and looking at different ways on dealing with the mobs/bosses. Overall, if I ever get the time/companions to play this game again, I totally would. 10/10 fun.

content:
er 19, 2013
												The Good:-The best combat system of any RPG I've ever played. The system involves having an abundance of awesome skills at your disposal and several fighting game mechanics. The system is perfect for creating a ton of different combos that flow together very nicely.-Leveling up is always rewarding. Not only will you see very noticable differences in your performance with new gear, new skills are unlocked frequently.-While the class selection may appear small at first, each class branches out into 2 paths twice. So with the current 6 classes available, that's really like having 24 classes.-Each class feels unique. This includes the classes that are made from branching out. Lunar Knights and Gladiators may both be Swordsmen, but the only similarity between the two will be a couple of basic skills and their character model.-PVP has a great amount of variety. You can join a 1 on 1 lobby to fully experience the fighting game mechanics, you can participate in hectic 16-player team deathmatches, free-for-alls, and "kill the other team's leader" matches, or you can play the ghouls mode, which is a standard zombie mode that functions well as a completely level-free form of PVP.-Higher-level PVE and PVP demand a high amount of skill from players.-Leveling up is mostly painless. There will be patches of grinding you'll do here and there, but the grinding in this game is much less repetitive than in other RPGs.-Every skill you are given has a purpose. There are very few skills that become obsolete.-Tons of stat builds to choose from.-The voice-acting is full of personality when it's there. Voice-acting is most prevalent during combat, with many skills making the character using them say something. Important NPCs also have voice-acted greeting and farewell lines.-The main story is solid and easy to follow, even if you're like me and skip through most of the dialogue. It will also provide cinematics to spice things up from time-to-time.-If you put in the time to read it, the dialogue for main and side quests is well-written and genuinely funny.-Locations are very diverse and well-designed.-A unique art direction that combines cute with badass perfectly.-It's easy to find parties at peak player activity times.-Tons of seasonal and update events with useful rewards.-A solid guild system with features such as custom guild emblems, guild storage, and guild buffs.The Bad:-The format of the world. While it's perfectly functional, it's a huge shame that this game isn't an open world. The only time you'll ever feel like you're in a populated world is when you're in a main town. As soon as you leave one, the only players you'll have any physical contact with is whoever is in your party, which only includes up to 3 other players at a time. There will be a few NPCs out in the non-main town areas, but they don't help the feeling of loneliness very much.-All PVE gameplay is instance-based, and the instances, while being highly detailed and just right in length, are usually a linear path. Sometimes quests will give you additional objectives besides getting to the end of an instance, but that only happens rarely.-Minimal character customization to start out with.-You'll have to ask around for info on the game's deeper mechanics such as paralyze, super armor, and knockdown.-Skills are not always described nearly well enough. Skill descriptions never provide information like how many invincibility frames a skill has, how strong it's ability to break super armor is, etc.-Armor sets that you don't buy with real money only have one appearence per rarity. For example, a common and a rare set of armor will look different, but a level 20 set of rare armor will look exactly the same as a level 50 set of rare armor. This happens in a few cases with weapons too, but not usually. Curiously, headgear is a part of all gear sets, but will never be visible on characters unless it's one of the epic-rarity headgears (which do actually have differing appearances compared to other epic headgears).-Server instability can be an issue at times.-The things that cost real money are terribly over-priced. A full set of cool-looking armor that gives some extra stat bonuses costs about $20, though you can reduce the price a bit if you're willing to "rent" the armor for a limited time instead. Having played Nexon games that use this format of over-priced microtransactions since 2005, I have never bought a single thing from these shops and have enjoyed the games anyway. As a side note, you can earn NX (the currency used for these microtransactions) for free, but the means of doing this often involve a LOT of personal information sharing to a LOT of shady websites. If you try to use fake personal information, you'll end up like me and get permanently banned from the service.(Overall, the cons aren't very significant, so just give this game a try)

number of helpful: 9 of 13 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
y 23
												[SRS][Respect the tag]TL;DR Cliffs:Review from a veteran of DN (back in 60 cap). I've also played a LOT of MMORPGs like WoW, Flyff, Raganarok Online, RS, MS, and more.Pros:Best combat system I've seen out of 11 MMORPGSkill-based gameplayDress-up Simulator 2017Skills are huge. Mounts are huger. Bosses are hugest.Game mechanics promote cooperative play.Fun communityGood storyline33 classes with wildly different playstyles.Balanced classesCons:Content is at level cap, grinding is mind-numbingly easy.LOL Economy. 6g a quest, 3k for a L-Grade enhancement ATTEMPT.RNG. It's depressing.Almost no character customization.PS2-era graphics.8/10, would return from hiatus again.Full ReviewThe game's changed a lot since I last played it. With every patch the power creep gets a little stronger. However, the instanced dungeons also get harder as well. For instance, this last patch added in a new class, the Arch Heretic, and updated our daily quest dungeons. We went from having bosses with maybe 20m hp to bosses wih about 200m.Updates:Game Devs keep the game regularly updated. The Devs are actually based out in Korea (known as kDN) and NA gets their updates a couple of months later. Luckily, this generally means that we get our updates prebalanced. Most recently, this meant our Tinkerer Awakening for the Adept class wasn't broken; we got it all in one patch. kDN, on the other hand, had the Adept class catapult to a top tier buffer, debuffer, and number 1 DPS before getting her rebalanced.Of course it's also bad thing, since ED's one of the worse publishers of DN and it takes about a month for new content to be translated. While I know they aren't the direct developers, having incomplete released content months after other publishers get it out.... it just strikes me as lazy. God knows I wouldn't play DN NA if it wasn't the only one available.The game is well balanced. Though it's hard to say sometimes since everyone hits OMGWTFBBQ damage at endgame. To place this in perspecive, you go through the storyline with up to 40k attack. Beginner cap equipment instantly puts you above 100k, not counting bonus multipliers from Elemental conversions and Awakened skills.Combat:The combat was amazing years ago and it's amazing now. In fact, I'd argue that it's even better now. While the game was more active back in 60 cap, the classes weren't balanced, with my capped Acrobats/Tempests being outdamaged by ungeared level 30 Sorceresses. Ouch. Now every class is about equal in terms of party benefit, with some being situationally better. This is a GREAT thing, since that means every class is accepted in public parties with the only criteria being your experience or gear.Moreover, the combat is really satisfying. The game, with its PS2 graphics, delivers some very impressive skills and combos, with large explosions of every color. Certain classes have really tight skill rotations and you have to keep up with managing them while dealing with Mechs.For instance, while fighting the first boss on Typhoon Krag Nest HC, you have to DPS the Gardener boss while killing any blue mushrooms counting down. While doing this, you have to stay away from any green mushrooms on the map if you're marked by the Orc Bomber. You have to dodge the Orc Bomber's attacks while keeping them from accidenally hitting the green mushrooms. If the blue mushroom counts down, or you accidentally hit the green mushroom cause the Gardener smacked you into them, the entire party takes a mapwide attack. You can tank these, but the harder Nests like have insta-kill mechanics that you MUST learn or you will kill your entire team.PvP:As for PvP, the combat is still really fun, fast, with intuitive and free-flowing combos. However, ladder rankings are unstable since so many new classes and awakenings are being added in. The meta changes before it's even developed. Yikes. The nice thing is that no one take PvP too seriously, and they won't rage just because they lost. PvP is completely skill based, and the developers have their own section just for PvP balancing.Even better, to help deal with power creep, every skill is rebalanced in PvP. A debuff that would normally last 30s becomes 10s, a. In a sense, PvP is another game entirely and one that I highly recommend getting into. WARNING: This game has one of the highest learning curves I've ever seen for PvP. You will lose and you will lose very badly until you learn all of the classes, combos, and i-frames.Player Friendly?The community is pretty solid. There are a few toxic people, but the game itself rewards cooperative play. You literally get more drops at the end of dungeons, use less Empowerment, and get team-revives just from having more people playing with you. Guilds are super nice and easy to get into, and they're always down to teach new and returning players.This last update updated a "Growth Guide" which gives new players a full set of Theano gear and Weapons. Generally, new players would have to spend a few weeks building up a set; now you're given one and can proceed to more endgame stuff without being straight carried.However, the economy is in shambles. Remember how I said ED takes what kDN developers update and release it here? Yup, they did that again. However, they never updated gold costs while simultaneously lowering gold acqusition to the lowest of the servers. The real killer is enhancement costs, which are necessary to tackle harder content.To put this into perspective, you get about 6g per end-game quest. (1g for "talking" quests). It costs a few hundred gold to CRAFT legendary equipment. It costs thousands to attempt to enhance it to an appropriate level (at like 10% enhancement rate...) let alone silly equipment like crests that add Final Damage for 40k+.It's gotten to the point where players SELL dungeon runs because it's faster and cheaper for normal people to pay geared people to bring them than to attempt to get geared themselves first. To put this into perspective again, one IDN HC run (you need at least 2 runs for a shoe) costs 3.5k gold.Now for the ugliest part; RNG and P2W. This game is slightly P2W, with extensive OP set bonuses for completing costume sets with accessories that can only be found in dragon eggs. Costume sets are $30, and dragon eggs are $1.50. These dragon egg items cannot be traded or shared, even with your own characters. Once RNG blesses you with a piece, you better pray that it's on a class you won't mind maining for a while.This newest Cold Mirage/Sadnyth set is notorious, with players reporting less than 0.2% drop rates for Sadnyth Tails. If you really want that tail, it'll most likely take you over $600 to get. Good luck. ED gives off 50 cents worth of points every day you log in though, so that helps a little.Misc:The classes are also gender locked. I didn't like it at first, but now I appreciate it, since it literally makes you the character in the DN storyline.There's a severe lack of customization. There's no points to upgrade Strength or Dexterity like traditional games. Your stats are based solely off of your equipment. You have little flexibility in what skills you get with Awakened skills requiring max level skills.You get like 4 hair colors to choose from. Any more and it's RNG or $.Note: To most of these negative reviews are people who lost their account when the game flipped publishers; You guys had over two months to switch. I lost my account too but I don't spend all day whining about it. Play or not, you can't say it's a bad game just because you didn't keep up with your updates. Please stop being the cancer in the gaming community who rate negatively just cause of one failed patch or ragequit.

er 14, 2013
												This game is great, I've got more than enough game time to prove that. The classes proved a refreshing twist on MMORPGs that many others fail to achieve. The combat is exciting and stylish on every class in both PvE and PvP even with unbalancing on classes. The story line is pretty interesting, if you decide to even pay attention to it. However this game is not without its fair share of flaws. I'll make a small list to explain some of the more pressing problems1. This IS a Nexon game, which if you know from their other games they treat the Chinese version of the game MUCH better.2. Stamina system, again another Nexon thing. Once you hit the (current) cap the game drains you stamina (called PWR here) in as little as two or three dungeon runs3. Juggling dominates PvP. You can find rooms that let you burn your PWR for medals known as "chill" rooms so it is not as big of a problem as the two aboveThis game is worth playing. However expect to be treated like crap by the customer support and just Nexon all together. It offers a great experience to both new and old MMORPG players.

9, 2015
												Great Game when it came out, now not so much. It was innovative and kind of first of its kind. The only problem I have with DN and the main reason I stopped playing it is- I felt lonely. DN is a race to the top kind of game. It wasn't like that in the beginning but slowly became that. Everyone is racing to the top/cap and then after a while you've got newbie towns that become an absolute desert, and you've got no one to do instances with. The only time those towns become populated again is when they release a new character. If you play this game with friends, then it'll be a fun game to play and I'd recommend it. However, if you're thinking about coming in by yourself, then I'd say don't bother. It'll be fun at first, but you'll eventually feel lonely and will stop playing. DN is also a highly competitive game. If you don't have a gaming mouse, don't even step into the arena.

												Dragon Nest is a game from Nexon, the evil minds behind Maple Story. This game plays very much like Vindictus with various tiers of difficulty in each mission area, different loot, different bosses/moves/hp imcreased, etc. The thing that separates this from Vindictus is the cuteness of it all. This is a very "cute" game where everything is nice and bright and the conversations you have with NPC's are downright funny quite often. You never know what they'll end up talking to you about before you accept a quest or are just improving relations with them.You can pick a few different classes but they are all gender locked. A fighter is male and a sorceress is female for example.This game is hard to describe if you haven't played Vindictus because that game has very similar ....everything! It's just a tad more.You can crafticular mission area and so on. It's worth trying this game just to see if you like it. I often sit down intending to do just one mission or two and end up playing for hours. Definitely the sign of a good game.

												While I have played this game for a long time, I've had my fun with it. The combo system is good, but rarely has any effects on actual gameplay other than PVP where literally you cannot win without better stats. This game isn't as Skill to Win as it used to be, according to most of my friends who have played it for a long time. Although this game has a pretty good base and whatnot, grinding on the same dungeons just becomes really boring. Do I recommend this game? Yes and no.The PVP system is a bit flawed, but I can see where it has its fun parts. The dungeon and EXP system itself are pretty good, looting system along with them. But I do not encourage buying stuff in this game with real money, since it's pretty much just a waste.The variety of classes in this game is also a good thing to mention. But some classes definitely rise up higher than others do, which really disappoints me.The story becomes really repetitive but the only entertaining parts are when you get to actually see the story of your own character. Other than that, it's just the main story of the game.As I said, I don't exactly recommend this game but I have solid hopes for it.

												This is easily the best MMO I have ever played. The combat in this game is the only 1 of its kind. Very fast paced and fluid. It feels and looks amazing when taking down huge groups of enemies in seconds. There will be almost 50 different job classes when the Assassin is released.
